content.thinking:
The issue is clear: GoReleaser failed because the release assets already exist. The `v0.2.0` release was already partially created (the release exists and some assets were uploaded), so when GoReleaser tried to upload them again, it got `422 Validation Failed - already_exists` errors.

This is a common issue when a release workflow is re-run or when a release was partially created. The fix is to either:
1. Delete the existing release and re-run the workflow
2. Or fix the workflow to handle this case (e.g., use `--skip=publish` or add `skip_upload: true` for existing assets)


The release at `v0.2.0` already exists with assets from a previous attempt, so GoReleaser can't overwrite them on the re-run. I need to either delete the release and retry, or modify the workflow to skip uploading assets that are already present.

file.content:
name: Release

on:
  push:
    tags:
      - 'v*'
  workflow_dispatch:
    inputs:
      cli_only:
        description: 'Build CLI binaries only (skip Docker images)'
        type: boolean
        default: true

env:
  REGISTRY: ghcr.io

jobs:
  # ── Determine build matrix ────────────────────────────────────────────────
  prepare:
    if: ${{ !inputs.cli_only }}
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    outputs:
      platforms: ${{ steps.platforms.outputs.value }}
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      - name: Determine platforms
        id: platforms
        run: |
          MSG=$(git log -1 --format=%B)
          if echo "$MSG" | grep -qi '\[multi-arch\]'; then
            echo 'value=["linux/amd64","linux/arm64"]' >> "$GITHUB_OUTPUT"
          else
            echo 'value=["linux/amd64"]' >> "$GITHUB_OUTPUT"
          fi

  # ── App image: build per platform (parallel) ──────────────────────────────
  app-build:
    needs: prepare
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    permissions:
      contents: read
      packages: write
    strategy:
      matrix:
        platform: ${{ fromJson(needs.prepare.outputs.platforms) }}
    steps:
      - name: Checkout
        uses: actions/checkout@v4

      - name: Set up QEMU
        uses: docker/setup-qemu-action@v3

      - name: Set up Docker Buildx
        uses: docker/setup-buildx-action@v3

      - name: Log in to GitHub Container Registry
        uses: docker/login-action@v3
        with:
          registry: ${{ env.REGISTRY }}
          username: ${{ github.actor }}
          password: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}

      - name: Extract metadata
        id: meta
        uses: docker/metadata-action@v5
        with:
          images: ${{ env.REGISTRY }}/thieso2/sandcastle

      - name: Build and push by digest
        id: build
        uses: docker/build-push-action@v6
        with:
          context: .
          platforms: ${{ matrix.platform }}
          labels: ${{ steps.meta.outputs.labels }}
          cache-from: type=gha,scope=app-${{ matrix.platform }}
          cache-to: type=gha,scope=app-${{ matrix.platform }},mode=max
          outputs: type=image,name=${{ env.REGISTRY }}/thieso2/sandcastle,push-by-digest=true,name-canonical=true,push=true
          build-args: |
            BUILD_GIT_SHA=${{ github.sha }}
            BUILD_GIT_DIRTY=
            BUILD_DATE=${{ github.event.head_commit.timestamp }}

      - name: Export digest
        run: |
          mkdir -p /tmp/digests
          digest="${{ steps.build.outputs.digest }}"
          touch "/tmp/digests/${digest#sha256:}"

      - name: Upload digest
        uses: actions/upload-artifact@v4
        with:
          name: app-digest-${{ strategy.job-index }}
          path: /tmp/digests/*
          if-no-files-found: error
          retention-days: 1

  # ── App image: merge into multi-arch manifest ─────────────────────────────
  app-merge:
    needs: app-build
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    permissions:
      contents: read
      packages: write
    steps:
      - name: Download digests
        uses: actions/download-artifact@v4
        with:
          path: /tmp/digests
          pattern: app-digest-*
          merge-multiple: true

      - name: Set up Docker Buildx
        uses: docker/setup-buildx-action@v3

      - name: Log in to GitHub Container Registry
        uses: docker/login-action@v3
        with:
          registry: ${{ env.REGISTRY }}
          username: ${{ github.actor }}
          password: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}

      - name: Extract metadata
        id: meta
        uses: docker/metadata-action@v5
        with:
          images: ${{ env.REGISTRY }}/thieso2/sandcastle
          tags: |
            type=semver,pattern={{version}}
            type=semver,pattern={{major}}.{{minor}}
            type=semver,pattern={{major}}
            type=raw,value=latest

      - name: Create manifest list and push
        working-directory: /tmp/digests
        run: |
          docker buildx imagetools create $(jq -cr '.tags | map("-t " + .) | join(" ")' <<< "$DOCKER_METADATA_OUTPUT_JSON") \
            $(printf '${{ env.REGISTRY }}/thieso2/sandcastle@sha256:%s ' *)

      - name: Inspect image
        run: docker buildx imagetools inspect ${{ env.REGISTRY }}/thieso2/sandcastle:latest

  # ── Sandbox image: build per platform (parallel) ──────────────────────────
  sandbox-build:
    needs: prepare
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    permissions:
      contents: read
      packages: write
    strategy:
      matrix:
        platform: ${{ fromJson(needs.prepare.outputs.platforms) }}
    steps:
      - name: Checkout
        uses: actions/checkout@v4

      - name: Set up QEMU
        uses: docker/setup-qemu-action@v3

      - name: Set up Docker Buildx
        uses: docker/setup-buildx-action@v3

      - name: Log in to GitHub Container Registry
        uses: docker/login-action@v3
        with:
          registry: ${{ env.REGISTRY }}
          username: ${{ github.actor }}
          password: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}

      - name: Extract metadata
        id: meta
        uses: docker/metadata-action@v5
        with:
          images: ${{ env.REGISTRY }}/thieso2/sandcastle-sandbox

      - name: Build and push by digest
        id: build
        uses: docker/build-push-action@v6
        with:
          context: images/sandbox
          platforms: ${{ matrix.platform }}
          labels: ${{ steps.meta.outputs.labels }}
          cache-from: type=gha,scope=sandbox-${{ matrix.platform }}
          cache-to: type=gha,scope=sandbox-${{ matrix.platform }},mode=max
          outputs: type=image,name=${{ env.REGISTRY }}/thieso2/sandcastle-sandbox,push-by-digest=true,name-canonical=true,push=true

      - name: Export digest
        run: |
          mkdir -p /tmp/digests
          digest="${{ steps.build.outputs.digest }}"
          touch "/tmp/digests/${digest#sha256:}"

      - name: Upload digest
        uses: actions/upload-artifact@v4
        with:
          name: sandbox-digest-${{ strategy.job-index }}
          path: /tmp/digests/*
          if-no-files-found: error
          retention-days: 1

  # ── Sandbox image: merge into multi-arch manifest ─────────────────────────
  sandbox-merge:
    needs: sandbox-build
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    permissions:
      contents: read
      packages: write
    steps:
      - name: Download digests
        uses: actions/download-artifact@v4
        with:
          path: /tmp/digests
          pattern: sandbox-digest-*
          merge-multiple: true

      - name: Set up Docker Buildx
        uses: docker/setup-buildx-action@v3

      - name: Log in to GitHub Container Registry
        uses: docker/login-action@v3
        with:
          registry: ${{ env.REGISTRY }}
          username: ${{ github.actor }}
          password: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}

      - name: Extract metadata
        id: meta
        uses: docker/metadata-action@v5
        with:
          images: ${{ env.REGISTRY }}/thieso2/sandcastle-sandbox
          tags: |
            type=semver,pattern={{version}}
            type=semver,pattern={{major}}.{{minor}}
            type=semver,pattern={{major}}
            type=raw,value=latest

      - name: Create manifest list and push
        working-directory: /tmp/digests
        run: |
          docker buildx imagetools create $(jq -cr '.tags | map("-t " + .) | join(" ")' <<< "$DOCKER_METADATA_OUTPUT_JSON") \
            $(printf '${{ env.REGISTRY }}/thieso2/sandcastle-sandbox@sha256:%s ' *)

      - name: Inspect image
        run: docker buildx imagetools inspect ${{ env.REGISTRY }}/thieso2/sandcastle-sandbox:latest

  # ── CLI binaries: build, sign, notarize, and attach to GitHub release ──
  cli-build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    permissions:
      contents: write
    steps:
      - name: Checkout
        uses: actions/checkout@v4
        with:
          fetch-depth: 0

      - name: Set up Go
        uses: actions/setup-go@v5
        with:
          go-version-file: vendor/sandcastle-cli/go.mod

      - name: Run GoReleaser (release)
        if: startsWith(github.ref, 'refs/tags/')
        uses: goreleaser/goreleaser-action@v6
        with:
          version: '~> v2'
          args: release --clean
          workdir: vendor/sandcastle-cli
        env:
          GITHUB_TOKEN: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}
          HOMEBREW_TAP_GITHUB_TOKEN: ${{ secrets.HOMEBREW_TAP_GITHUB_TOKEN }}
          MACOS_SIGN_P12: ${{ secrets.MACOS_SIGN_P12 }}
          MACOS_SIGN_PASSWORD: ${{ secrets.MACOS_SIGN_PASSWORD }}
          MACOS_NOTARY_ISSUER_ID: ${{ secrets.MACOS_NOTARY_ISSUER_ID }}
          MACOS_NOTARY_KEY_ID: ${{ secrets.MACOS_NOTARY_KEY_ID }}
          MACOS_NOTARY_KEY: ${{ secrets.MACOS_NOTARY_KEY }}

      - name: Attach installer to release
        if: startsWith(github.ref, 'refs/tags/')
        env:
          GH_TOKEN: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}
        run: gh release upload ${{ github.ref_name }} installer.sh --clobber

      - name: Run GoReleaser (snapshot)
        if: ${{ !startsWith(github.ref, 'refs/tags/') }}
        uses: goreleaser/goreleaser-action@v6
        with:
          version: '~> v2'
          args: release --snapshot --clean
          workdir: vendor/sandcastle-cli
        env:
          GITHUB_TOKEN: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}

      - name: Upload CLI binaries as artifacts
        if: ${{ !startsWith(github.ref, 'refs/tags/') }}
        uses: actions/upload-artifact@v4
        with:
          name: sandcastle-cli
          path: |
            vendor/sandcastle-cli/dist/Sandcastle_*/sandcastle
            vendor/sandcastle-cli/dist/checksums.txt
          retention-days: 7

content.thinking:
Now I understand the full picture. The v0.2.0 release already exists with all assets uploaded (from a previous run of this same workflow). When the workflow was re-run (or ran a second time), GoReleaser tried to upload the same assets again and got `already_exists` errors.

Looking at the release, it actually has all 5 assets already:
- checksums.txt
- sandcastle-darwin-amd64.tar.gz
- sandcastle-darwin-arm64.tar.gz
- sandcastle-linux-amd64.tar.gz
- sandcastle-linux-arm64.tar.gz


The release is actually complete—the workflow just failed because it was a re-run. I need to check the GoReleaser configuration to see if there's a way to handle existing assets gracefully, and I'm also examining the timestamps more carefully to understand the sequence of events between the first successful run and this failed re-run.

Looking at the GoReleaser v2 documentation, there's a `release.replace_existing_artifacts` option that should handle this situation.

The real issue is that the workflow triggered twice for the same tag—the first run completed successfully and created the release with all assets, then the second run failed trying to add the same artifacts. Since the release is already complete with all five assets, the immediate problem is resolved, but I should look into preventing duplicate workflow triggers or configuring GoReleaser to handle re-runs gracefully.

content.text: The `v0.2.0` release already has all 5 assets — it was completed by a previous workflow run. This run failed because GoReleaser tried to re-upload assets that already exist. Let me check the GoReleaser config to add a preventive fix.

file.content:
version: 2

builds:
  - binary: sandcastle
    env:
      - CGO_ENABLED=0
    goos:
      - linux
      - darwin
    goarch:
      - amd64
      - arm64
    ldflags:
      - -s -w -X github.com/sandcastle/cli/cmd.Version={{ .Version }}

archives:
  - formats: [tar.gz]
    name_template: sandcastle-{{ .Os }}-{{ .Arch }}

checksum:
  name_template: checksums.txt
  algorithm: sha256

notarize:
  macos:
    - enabled: '{{ isEnvSet "MACOS_SIGN_P12" }}'
      sign:
        certificate: "{{ .Env.MACOS_SIGN_P12 }}"
        password: "{{ .Env.MACOS_SIGN_PASSWORD }}"
      notarize:
        issuer_id: "{{ .Env.MACOS_NOTARY_ISSUER_ID }}"
        key_id: "{{ .Env.MACOS_NOTARY_KEY_ID }}"
        key: "{{ .Env.MACOS_NOTARY_KEY }}"

brews:
  - repository:
      owner: thieso2
      name: homebrew-tap
      token: "{{ .Env.HOMEBREW_TAP_GITHUB_TOKEN }}"
    directory: Formula
    homepage: "https://github.com/thieso2/Sandcastle"
    description: "CLI for Sandcastle, a self-hosted shared Docker sandbox platform"
    license: "MIT"
    test: |
      system "#{bin}/sandcastle", "version"

changelog:
  sort: asc
  filters:
    exclude:
      - "^Merge"

content.thinking:
Now I see the issue clearly. The GoReleaser config doesn't have `release.replace_existing_artifacts` set. When the workflow runs a second time for the same tag (e.g., due to a re-run), it fails because assets already exist.

The fix is to add `release.replace_existing_artifacts: true` to the GoReleaser config. In GoReleaser v2, this option replaces existing artifacts instead of failing.

But wait - looking at the log, there are actually TWO issues:

1. GoReleaser fails when release assets already exist (the main issue)
2. The `brews` deprecation warning: "brews is being phased out in favor of homebrew_casks"


Looking at the logs more carefully, the first run must have succeeded and created the release with all assets. This re-run failed only on the cli-build job while everything else passed, so the release itself is actually complete. The immediate problem is resolved, but I should still add `replace_existing_artifacts` to make the workflow idempotent and address the `brews` deprecation warning.

The deprecation message mentions `homebrew_casks`, but that's for casks, not formulas. According to GoReleaser v2 docs, `brews` was actually renamed to `homebrew`. Since it's just a warning, I'll focus on the actual fix first and add the replace artifacts option to the release configuration.

The issue is that `.goreleaser.yaml` has no `release` section, so GoReleaser fails when assets already exist (e.g., on re-runs). The fix is to add `replace_existing_artifacts: true`.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about the GoReleaser v2 brews deprecation and its replacement:

## Deprecation Details

The `brews` section was deprecated in v2.10, and Homebrew Casks should be used instead. The old brews section is deprecated and should be removed in the next major version (v3, not planned date yet) unless someone finds a big reason not to.

## Replacement: `homebrew_casks`

A new `homebrew_casks` section was introduced that does the right thing. In most cases, you only need to rename brews to homebrew_casks and that's it.

## Context for the Change

Historically, the brews section was kind of a hack—in Homebrew, Formulas are supposed to be used to build something from source and then install it, but GoReleaser was leveraging it to install something that was already built elsewhere. The new `homebrew_casks` section provides the proper way to handle pre-built binaries in Homebrew.

input.prompt: Show me the YAML configuration for homebrew_casks. What are the key differences from the old brews config? Show me a complete example.

content.content:
# Homebrew Casks Configuration in GoReleaser

## YAML Configuration Overview

The `homebrew_casks` section allows you to generate and publish Homebrew Casks to a repository after releasing to GitHub, GitLab, or Gitea. Here are the key configuration fields:

**Essential fields:**
- `name` - Cask name (defaults to project name)
- `ids` - Archive IDs to include (empty means all)
- `binaries` - Binary names inside the cask
- `repository` - Target tap repository details
- `url` - Download URL configuration with templates and parameters
- `homepage` - Application homepage
- `description` - Software description

**Advanced options:**
- `alternative_names` - Versioned cask variants (Pro feature)
- `app` - DMG app instead of binary (Pro feature)
- `manpages` - Path to manpage files
- `completions` - Shell completion configurations
- `hooks` - Pre/post install/uninstall lifecycle procedures
- `dependencies` - Cask and formula dependencies
- `pull_request` - Create PRs instead of direct pushes
- `custom_block` - Custom Ruby methods for advanced tasks

## Key Differences from Brews

The documentation references "Homebrew Formulas (deprecated)" as a separate feature. Casks differ by:

> "use only the DMG files instead of archives"

This indicates casks emphasize app distribution differently than formula-based approaches, supporting macOS-specific packaging like DMG files and app bundles.

## Complete Example

```yaml
homebrew_casks:
  - name: myapp
    alternative_names:
      - myapp@{{ .Major }}.{{ .Minor }}
    ids:
      - linux
      - macos
    binaries:
      - myapp
    homepage: "https://example.com"
    description: "Fast and easy application"
    
    url:
      template: "https://github.com/owner/repo/releases/download/{{ .Tag }}/{{ .ArtifactName }}"
      verified: "github.com/owner/repo/"
    
    hooks:
      post:
        install: |
          if OS.mac?
            system_command "/usr/bin/xattr", args: ["-dr", "com.apple.quarantine", "#{staged_path}/myapp"]
          end
    
    repository:
      owner: myuser
      name: homebrew-myapp
      branch: main
      pull_request:
        enabled: true
        draft: false
```

content.thinking:
Now I understand. The `brews` → `homebrew_casks` migration is mostly a rename, but casks work slightly differently - they're more appropriate for pre-built binaries (which is what GoReleaser produces).

However, looking at the existing config, the `brews` section creates a Homebrew **formula** in the tap repo. The `homebrew_casks` creates a Homebrew **cask**. These are different things in Homebrew:
- **Formula**: Typically for CLI tools, installed via `brew install`
- **Cask**: Typically for GUI apps, installed via `brew install --cask`


For a CLI tool like `sandcastle`, a formula is actually more appropriate than a cask, but GoReleaser deprecated formulas because they were being used to distribute pre-built binaries—which is technically what casks are designed for. The migration would change the tap structure from `Formula/Sandcastle.rb` to `Casks/sandcastle.rb`, which means users would need to install it with `brew install --cask sandcastle` instead of just `brew install sandcastle`.

GoReleaser has a point that using formulas for pre-built binaries is a workaround, though many CLI tools still do it. But the real issue here is the `replace_existing_artifacts` setting, so I'll focus on that fix first—adding `release.replace_existing_artifacts: true` to the `.goreleaser.yaml` file. The `brews` deprecation warning can be addressed later as a separate improvement.

Wait, let me reconsider what the user actually needs. They asked me to analyze and fix the issue, which is fundamentally about the release being run twice for the same tag. The workflow is triggered on tag pushes matching `v*`, so either the tag was re-pushed or the workflow was manually re-run, causing the second attempt to fail when trying to upload artifacts that already existed. Looking at the release timestamps, it was created and published within a few minutes on February 12th, 2026.

The solution is to configure GoReleaser to handle this scenario gracefully. I should look into the `release.mode` option in GoReleaser v2, which allows me to specify how to handle existing releases—either by replacing them entirely, keeping existing ones, or appending new artifacts. Setting this appropriately would make the workflow idempotent so that re-runs don't fail.

content.text:
Now I have the full picture. Here's the analysis:

**Root cause**: The `v0.2.0` release was already fully created by a previous successful workflow run (~15:35). This run (~15:43) was a re-run that failed because GoReleaser can't upload assets that already exist.

**Fix**: Add `release.replace_existing_artifacts: true` to `.goreleaser.yaml` so re-runs are idempotent.

content.text:
Done. The fix adds `release.replace_existing_artifacts: true` to `.goreleaser.yaml` so that re-running the release workflow for the same tag will overwrite existing assets instead of failing with `422 already_exists`.

**Note:** GoReleaser also warns that `brews` is deprecated in favor of `homebrew_casks` — this is a non-breaking warning for now but worth migrating eventually.
